title: Authors and Citation
text: Staley J, Burgess S (2017). “Semiparametric methods estimation nonlinear exposure-outcome relationship using instrumental variables application Mendelian randomization.” Genetic epidemiology, 41(4), 341–352. doi:10.1002/gepi.22041.
code: @Article{nlmr,   author = {J.R. Staley and S. Burgess},   title = {Semiparametric methods for estimation of a nonlinear exposure-outcome relationship using instrumental variables with application to Mendelian randomization},   year = {2017},   doi = {10.1002/gepi.22041},   journal = {Genetic epidemiology},   volume = {41},   number = {4},   pages = {341--352}, }

title: Non-linear Mendelian randomisation
text: package used assess non-linear exposure-outcome relationships using instrumental variable (IV) analysis context Mendelian randomisation (MR). package, two IV methods investigating shape exposure-outcome relationship: fractional polynomial method (fracpoly_mr) piecewise linear method (piecewise_mr). population (.e. one-sample) divided strata using exposure distribution, causal effect estimated, referred localized average causal effect (LACE), stratum. fractional polynomial method fits across LACE using meta-regression. piecewise linear method estimates continuous piecewise linear function consecutively adding LACE together.

title: Non-linear Mendelian randomisation
text: fracpoly_mr: method performs MR analysis using fractional polynomials. piecewise_mr: method performs MR analysis using piecewise linear function.

title: Non-linear Mendelian randomisation
code: # Libraries library(nlmr)  # IV (g), exposure (x) & outcome (y) epsx <- rexp(10000) u <- runif(10000, 0, 1) g <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.3) epsy <- rnorm(10000) ag <- 0.25 x <- 1 + ag * g + u + epsx y <- 0.15 * x^2 + 0.8 * u + epsy  # Covariates (covar) c1 <- rnorm(10000) c2 <- rnorm(10000) c3 <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.33) covar <- data.frame(c1 = c1, c2 = c2, c3 = as.factor(c3))  # Analyses fp <- fracpoly_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, d = 1, ci = "model_se",   fig = TRUE ) summary(fp) plm <- piecewise_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, nboot = 100,   fig = TRUE ) summary(plm)

title: Non-linear Mendelian randomisation
text: Staley JR Burgess S. Semiparametric methods estimation non-linear exposure-outcome relationship using instrumental variables application Mendelian randomization. Genet Epidemiol 2017;41(4):341-352.

title: Fractional polynomial Mendelian randomization — fracpoly_mr
text: fracpoly_mr performs Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis fitting fractional polynomial models localised average causal effects using meta-regression.

title: Fractional polynomial Mendelian randomization — fracpoly_mr
code: fracpoly_mr(   y,   x,   g,   covar = NULL,   family = "gaussian",   q = 10,   xpos = "mean",   method = "FE",   d = 1,   pd = 0.05,   ci = "model_se",   nboot = 100,   fig = FALSE,   ref = mean(x),   pref_x = "x",   pref_x_ref = "x",   pref_y = "y",   ci_type = "overall",   ci_quantiles = 10,   breaks = NULL )

title: Fractional polynomial Mendelian randomization — fracpoly_mr
text: y vector outcome values x vector exposure values g instrumental variable covar data.frame covariates family description error distribution link function used model character string naming either gaussian (.e. "gaussian" continuous data) binomial (.e. "binomial" binary data) family function (default: "gaussian") q number quantiles exposure distribution split within causal effect fitted, known localised average causal effects (LACE) (default: 10) xpos position used relate x localised average causal effect, can either mean x-values within quantile percentile (e.g. 0.5 corresponds median value) (default: "mean") method meta-regression method parsed metafor package, e.g. fixed-effects model (default: "FE") d fractional polynomial degree, options : 1, 2, "" (default: 1) pd p-value cut-choosing best-fitting fractional polynomial degree 2 best-fitting fractional polynomial degree 1, used d = "" (default: 0.05) ci type 95% confidence interval, three options: () using model standard errors ("model_se"), (ii) using bootstrap standard errors ("bootstrap_se"), (iii) using bootstrap percentile confidence intervals ("bootstrap_per") (default: "model_se") nboot number bootstrap replications (default: 100) fig logical statement whether user wants results displayed figure (default: FALSE) ref reference point figure, value function represents expected difference outcome compared reference value exposure set different values (default: mean(x)) pref_x prefix/label x-axis (default: "x") pref_x_ref prefix reference value displayed y-axis (default: "x") pref_y prefix/label y-axis (default: "y") ci_type type confidence interval displayed graph, confidence intervals either presented bands across range x (option: "overall") error bars mean quantile x (option: "quantile") (default:) ci_quantiles number quantiles confidence intervals displayed (default: 10) breaks breaks y-axis figure

title: Fractional polynomial Mendelian randomization — fracpoly_mr
text: fracpoly_mr returns list non-linear MR results fractional polynomial MR approach: n number individuals model model specifications: number quantiles (q), position used relate x LACE quantiles (xpos), type confidence interval constructed (ci), number bootstrap replications performed (nboot) powers powers chosen polynomial coefficients regression estimates: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se), lower 95% confidence interval (lci), upper 95% confidence interval (uci), p-value (pval) lace localised average causal effect estimate quantile: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se), lower 95% confidence interval (lci), upper 95% confidence interval (uci), p-value (pval) xcoef association instrument exposure quantile: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se) p_tests p-value non-linearity tests: p-value test fractional polynomial degrees (fp_d1_d2), p-value fractional polynomial non-linearity test (fp), p-value quadratic test (quad), p-value Cochran Q test (Q) p_heterogeneity p-value heterogeneity: p-value Cochran Q heterogeneity test (Q), p-value trend test (trend).

title: Fractional polynomial Mendelian randomization — fracpoly_mr
code: # IV (g), exposure (x) & outcome (y) epsx <- rexp(10000) u <- runif(10000, 0, 1) g <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.3) epsy <- rnorm(10000) ag <- 0.25 x <- 1 + ag * g + u + epsx y <- 0.15 * x^2 + 0.8 * u + epsy  # Covariates (covar) c1 <- rnorm(10000) c2 <- rnorm(10000) c3 <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.33) covar <- data.frame(c1 = c1, c2 = c2, c3 = as.factor(c3))  # Analyses fp <- fracpoly_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, d = 1, ci = "model_se",   fig = TRUE ) summary(fp) #> Call: fracpoly_mr #>  #> Number of individuals: 10000; Quantiles: 10; 95%CI: Model based SEs #>  #> Powers: 2 #>  #> Coefficients: #>   Estimate Std. Error 95%CI Lower 95%CI Upper   p.value     #> 2  0.15217    0.01350     0.12571      0.1786 < 2.2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Non-linearity tests #> Fractional polynomial degree p-value: 0.544 #> Fractional polynomial non-linearity p-value: 0.0029 #> Quadratic p-value: 0.00275 #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.125 #>  #> Heterogeneity tests #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.0137 #> Trend p-value: 0.337  plm <- piecewise_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, nboot = 100,   fig = TRUE ) summary(plm) #> Call: piecewise_mr #>  #> Number of individuals: 10000; Quantiles: 10; Number of bootstrap replications: 100 #>  #> LACE: #>     Estimate Std. Error 95%CI Lower 95%CI Upper   p.value     #> 1   0.342197   0.210671   -0.070717      0.7551 0.1043069     #> 2   0.711039   0.205134    0.308976      1.1131 0.0005278 *** #> 3   0.502861   0.210960    0.089380      0.9163 0.0171403 *   #> 4   0.546710   0.209581    0.135931      0.9575 0.0090918 **  #> 5   0.719374   0.208304    0.311098      1.1277 0.0005534 *** #> 6   0.946776   0.198864    0.557002      1.3365 1.927e-06 *** #> 7   0.853977   0.206361    0.449509      1.2584 3.499e-05 *** #> 8   0.781698   0.215367    0.359579      1.2038 0.0002838 *** #> 9   1.300118   0.221458    0.866061      1.7342 4.339e-09 *** #> 10  1.008924   0.426081    0.173804      1.8440 0.0178887 *   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Non-linearity tests #> Quadratic p-value: 0.00275 #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.125 #>  #> Heterogeneity tests #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.0137 #> Trend p-value: 0.425

title: Localised average causal effects — lace
text: lace computes localised average causal effect quantile.

title: Localised average causal effects — lace
code: lace(   y,   x,   g,   covar = NULL,   q,   x0q,   xc_sub = TRUE,   family = "gaussian",   xpos = "mean" )

title: Localised average causal effects — lace
text: y vector outcome values x vector exposure values g instrumental variable covar data.frame covariates q number quantiles exposure distribution split within causal effect fitted, known localised average causal effects (LACE) (default: 10) x0q quantiles x0 (IV-free exposure) xc_sub compute association exposure insturment quantile x0 family description error distribution link function used model character string naming either gaussian (.e. "gaussian" continuous data) binomial (.e. "binomial" binary data) family function (default: "gaussian") xpos position used relate x localised average causal effect, can either mean x-values within quantile percentile (e.g. 0.5 corresponds median value) (default: "mean")

title: Localised average causal effects — lace
text: lace returns data.frame LACE quantile: coef LACE quantile coef_se standard error LACE quantile xmean mean exposure quantile xcoef_sub association exposure instrument quantile xcoef_sub_se standard error association exposure instrument quantile

title: Piecewise linear Mendelian randomization — piecewise_mr
text: piecewise_mr performs Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis fitting piecewise linear function localised average causal effects.

title: Piecewise linear Mendelian randomization — piecewise_mr
code: piecewise_mr(   y,   x,   g,   covar = NULL,   family = "gaussian",   q = 10,   xpos = "mean",   nboot = 100,   fig = TRUE,   ref = mean(x),   pref_x = "x",   pref_x_ref = "x",   pref_y = "y",   ci_quantiles = 10,   breaks = NULL )

title: Piecewise linear Mendelian randomization — piecewise_mr
text: y vector outcome values x vector exposure values g instrumental variable covar data.frame covariates family description error distribution link function used model character string naming either gaussian (.e. "gaussian" continuous data) binomial (.e. "binomial" binary data) family function (default: "gaussian") q number quantiles exposure distribution split within causal effect fitted, known localised average causal effects (LACE) (default: 10) nboot number bootstrap replications (default: 100) fig logical statement whether user wants results displayed figure (default: TRUE) ref reference point figure, value function represents expected difference outcome compared reference value exposure set different values (default: mean(x)) pref_x prefix/label x-axis (default: "x") pref_x_ref prefix reference value displayed y-axis (default: "x") pref_y prefix/label y-axis (default: "y") ci_quantiles number quantiles confidence intervals displayed (default: 10) breaks breaks y-axis figure

title: Piecewise linear Mendelian randomization — piecewise_mr
text: piecewise_mr returns list non-linear MR results piecewise linear function MR approach: n number individuals model model specifications: number quantiles (q), number bootstrap replications performed (nboot) coefficients regression estimates: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se), lower 95% confidence interval (lci), upper 95% confidence interval (uci), p-value (pval) lace localised average causal effect estimate quantile: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se), lower 95% confidence interval (lci), upper 95% confidence interval (uci), p-value (pval) xcoef association instrument exposure quantile: regression coefficients (beta), standard errors regression coefficients (se) p_tests p-value non-linearity tests: p-value quadratic test (quad), p-value Cochran Q test (Q) p_heterogeneity p-value heterogeneity: p-value Cochran Q heterogeneity test (Q), p-value trend test (trend).

title: Piecewise linear Mendelian randomization — piecewise_mr
code: # IV (g), exposure (x) & outcome (y) epsx <- rexp(10000) u <- runif(10000, 0, 1) g <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.3) epsy <- rnorm(10000) ag <- 0.25 x <- 1 + ag * g + u + epsx y <- 0.15 * x^2 + 0.8 * u + epsy  # Covariates (covar) c1 <- rnorm(10000) c2 <- rnorm(10000) c3 <- rbinom(10000, 2, 0.33) covar <- data.frame(c1 = c1, c2 = c2, c3 = as.factor(c3))  # Analyses fp <- fracpoly_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, d = 1, ci = "model_se",   fig = TRUE ) summary(fp) #> Call: fracpoly_mr #>  #> Number of individuals: 10000; Quantiles: 10; 95%CI: Model based SEs #>  #> Powers: 2 #>  #> Coefficients: #>   Estimate Std. Error 95%CI Lower 95%CI Upper   p.value     #> 2 0.126424   0.013415    0.100130      0.1527 < 2.2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Non-linearity tests #> Fractional polynomial degree p-value: 0.172 #> Fractional polynomial non-linearity p-value: 0.0247 #> Quadratic p-value: 0.0217 #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.0396 #>  #> Heterogeneity tests #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.918 #> Trend p-value: 0.337  plm <- piecewise_mr(   y = y, x = x, g = g, covar = covar,   family = "gaussian", q = 10, nboot = 100,   fig = TRUE ) summary(plm) #> Call: piecewise_mr #>  #> Number of individuals: 10000; Quantiles: 10; Number of bootstrap replications: 100 #>  #> LACE: #>     Estimate Std. Error 95%CI Lower 95%CI Upper   p.value     #> 1   0.787235   0.200026    0.395184      1.1793 8.297e-05 *** #> 2   0.567541   0.205517    0.164727      0.9704  0.005753 **  #> 3   0.033646   0.211452   -0.380801      0.4481  0.873576     #> 4   0.548251   0.201303    0.153696      0.9428  0.006459 **  #> 5   0.364133   0.204394   -0.036479      0.7647  0.074827 .   #> 6   0.564660   0.211310    0.150494      0.9788  0.007536 **  #> 7   0.931976   0.216313    0.508002      1.3559 1.644e-05 *** #> 8   0.858192   0.207341    0.451805      1.2646 3.488e-05 *** #> 9   0.800382   0.204374    0.399809      1.2010 8.993e-05 *** #> 10  1.492730   0.484477    0.543155      2.4423  0.002062 **  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Non-linearity tests #> Quadratic p-value: 0.0217 #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.0396 #>  #> Heterogeneity tests #> Cochran Q p-value: 0.918 #> Trend p-value: 0.337
